Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Synthetic Angiotensin-II in Severe Burn Injury

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults with severe burn injury requiring vasoactive support. Eligibility criteria included age over 18 and burn injury covering more than 20% of total body surface area.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received synthetic AT-II, while the control group received standard catecholamine-based therapy.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy and safety of synthetic angiotensin-II (AT-II) compared to standard catecholamine-based therapy in acute burn shock resuscitation and septic shock in burn patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was mean arterial pressure (MAP) improvement within 24 hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the AT-II group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the AT-II group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The AT-II group showed a significant improvement in MAP (mean difference = 5.2 mm Hg, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the AT-II group and 1% of the control group, primarily mild gastrointestinal side-effects.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
